sections.title: Gentle extractions with clear surgical planning
sections.body: When a tooth can’t be saved, we remove it with care, protect surrounding tissue, and guide you through healing and replacement options.
bullets: Calm assessments that explain when extraction is the safest route
Minimally invasive techniques to protect bone and gum
Aftercare and future planning for implants, bridges, or dentures

sections.title: Situations that may need extraction or surgery
items: Severe decay or fracture where a filling or crown cannot seal the tooth
Persistent infection after root canal or structural cracks to the root
Impacted or problematic wisdom teeth causing pain or crowding
Advanced gum disease with loose, uncomfortable teeth
Orthodontic or prosthetic planning where space or stability is needed
sections.strapline: If you experience rapid swelling, spreading infection, or difficulty swallowing, treat it as urgent and contact us for emergency dentistry advice.

sections.title: Plan the safest removal and next steps
items: Emergency relief and assessment if pain or infection is acute (/treatments/emergency-dentistry)
Simple or surgical extraction with clear aftercare (/treatments/extractions-and-oral-surgery)
Socket preservation or grafting when future implants are planned (/treatments/implants-bone-grafting)
Healing and replacement pathways including bridges, dentures, or implants (/treatments/implants)

sections.title: Planned steps for predictable healing
items: Assessment: X-rays or CBCT to map roots, nerves, and sinus position
Comfort: Local anaesthetic and gentle explanation before we begin
Access: Precise gum and bone access only where needed
Removal: Sectioning or elevation to ease the tooth out with minimal force
Site care: Thorough cleaning, possible grafting, and careful suturing
Instructions: Clear guidance on rest, cleaning, and what to expect during healing
Review: Follow-up to confirm the site is settling and discuss next steps

sections.title: Digital planning that protects nearby structures
sections.body: CBCT imaging, surgical planning, and fine instruments help us visualise roots, nerves, and sinus spaces so we can work accurately and reduce trauma.
sections.mediaHint: CBCT-guided planning and minimally invasive instruments

sections.title: Support from anaesthetic to healing
items: Local anaesthetic for comfort; sedation dentistry can be discussed for anxious patients
Measured technique to limit swelling and bruising
Guidance on pain relief, rest, and eating while the site heals
Instructions to keep the area clean without disturbing the socket
Direct contact if bleeding, swelling, or discomfort changes unexpectedly

sections.title: Transparent guidance before removal
sections.body: We outline potential risks such as dry socket, sinus communication, nerve proximity, or the need for sectioning so you know what to expect. Where a tooth might be saved with restorative care, we will explain that option too.
bullets: Discussion of saving versus removing a tooth with restorative or endodontic care
Clear consent for complex roots, impacted teeth, or medical considerations
Alternatives such as monitoring or referral to surgical colleagues when indicated
Planning for provisional solutions while you heal

sections.title: Stable healing and future options
sections.body: With careful socket care, most sites heal smoothly in a few weeks. We guide you on timing for implants, bridges, or dentures so you know when replacement can safely begin.
bullets: Monitoring to confirm bone and gum health before replacement
Advice on protecting the site to maintain bone volume
Discussion of implant planning or bridgework once healing allows
Ongoing reviews to keep surrounding teeth and gums healthy

faqs.question: Will I feel pain during the extraction?
faqs.answer: The area is numbed thoroughly with local anaesthetic. You may feel pressure but should not feel sharp pain, and sedation options can be discussed if you are anxious.

faqs.question: How long is recovery?
faqs.answer: Most people are comfortable after a few days with steady improvement over 1–2 weeks. We give written instructions to support smooth healing.

faqs.question: Can the tooth be replaced?
faqs.answer: Yes. We will discuss timing for implants, bridges, or dentures once the area is stable, and we can provide provisional solutions if needed.

faqs.question: What if the tooth could be saved?
faqs.answer: If a filling, crown, or root canal could provide a predictable result, we’ll explain that option first so you can make an informed choice.

sections.title: Need advice about a troublesome tooth?
sections.body: We’ll review your options, plan comfortable removal if needed, and map the best path to restore your smile.
